content:
Houndour 050/L-P Reviving Legends PrizeAbout #This Houndour card was a participation prize for the Reviving Legends Release Commemoration Tournament held at a Challenge Plaza event in Febuary 2010, in Japan.
Players would compete in single-elimination matches, with a total of 5 rounds. Each participant would receive either a Scyther or Houndour card. The promo cards were distributed randomly, with each player receiving only one.
The cards were cosmos holofoil variants & featured the set‚Äôs logo stamped on the card. On the Houndour the set stamp was in the bottom right corner of the artwork, with the Pok√©mon logo and the text “Legend” in the top left corner. For the Scyther, it was the opposite with the logo in to the top right and set stamp in the bottom left.
Looking for more? #You can view my personal collection here Have thoughts or questions? Curious about this topic? Let‚Äôs chat about it.
Leave a comment on ùïè ‚Äî I‚Äôd love to hear from you!
https://t.co/cvbmKyTaAB
— PokiPlanet (@pokiplanet) September 1, 2025
title: PSA 9 Houndour Reviving Legends Prize

content:
Teddiursa 010/L-P HG & SS Release CampaignAbout #In the year 2009 in Japan, 1 card out of 6 special stamped cards were given out to customers at random when they purchased 2 or more booster packs from the HeartGold Collection & SoulSilver Collection
The following cards were made available to buyers:
Chikorita 005/L-P Cyndaquil 006/L-P Totodile 007/L-P Mareep 008/L-P Phanphy 009/L-P Teddiursa 010/L-P The cards feature the HG & SS Collection set logo on the bottom of the artwork of the card and also have a gold stamp at the bottom right of the card above the illustrator name that reads “Release commemorative card”.
Looking for more? #You can view my personal collection here Have thoughts or questions? Curious about this topic? Let‚Äôs chat about it.
Leave a comment on ùïè ‚Äî I‚Äôd love to hear from you!
https://t.co/TgdbDrkBwF
— PokiPlanet (@pokiplanet) August 27, 2025
title: PSA 9 Teddiursa HG & SS Release Campaign

content:
[09 June 2025]
The E4 Art Contest is an annual event hosted by Elite Fourum, a community focused on Pok√©mon card collecting. Officially known as the E4 Art & Illustration Contest, it invites participants of all skill levels to submit artwork in four diverse categories. The contest is free to enter, encourages participation from both novice and experienced artists, and emphasizes inclusivity, welcoming original creations, childlike drawings, and digital art.
This is the first time i will be entering. but not for myself, for my 8 year old daughter Leila (Lee-la) She is a fantastic little artist with her own style and enjoys spending time drawing on paper as well as digitally on her tablet. Regardless of the results on the forum i am planning on creating her a card featuring her art for her as well as a prize for her effort.
I entered her into 2 category’s i thought she would excel at
Child Drawing Recreation Recreation #She first set out at Recreation, i asked her what her favorite Pokemon was and she said Eevee & Pikachu. i visited pkmncards.com on my Laptop and showed her Eevee cards and Pikachu cards until she chose one to draw, She chose the common Generations Pikachu illustrated by Atsuko Nishida. Atsuko Nishida is one of my favorite artist’s, maybe my #1.. though it’s hard to choose.
Throughout my TCG collecting there has been many times i’ve come across a card art that really grabs my attention and it turns out to be Atsuko Nishida. So i was especially surprised when she chose this card and again i look down and see it’s Nishida. She said she likes the style and that it’s similar to hers. I downloaded the image, cropped it and sent it to her tablet for her to recreate.
I left her to it for a while but checked on her from time to time to see how she was doing, i could see she was excited and knew exactly what she was going to do for this art piece. She loves drawing her own things with her own style, this is the first time she has ever drawn Pokemon.
She showed me the finished piece, and we are both very happy with it. She was literally bouncing up and down with excitement and pride with what she had done. I am also very proud of her, especially since this has all been self taught. In my opinion she is extremely talented and has a great imagination.
Leila’s Pikachu #That was enough for now, she worked hard on it and was eager to continue, but it was time for bed.
Child Drawing #She had free reign now, she can draw in her own style and im excited to see what she will produce.
[28 June 2025]
This one took her the longest, she finished just in time for the submission period opening up for the contest!
I am immensely proud of her and will be rewarding her for her efforts!
Eevee Espresso #Card i made for her featuring her artYou can view the contest thread over on efour
I am grateful for the community over at efour for hosting the event again and immensely proud of my daughter Leila for her submissions!
Win or loose, it created many great family memories and hopefully one she won’t forget as she gets older.
Leila - Age 8Past Artwork #If you would like to see some more of her art here are a few pieces i pulled from her tablet.
Comments from the contest #[22 July 2025]
The Results are in #E4 ART CONTEST 2025 Thread! (Results! ! !)
The competition was tough, everyone’s submissions were well put together. Leila received an honorable mention for being within a few votes to the top 3. I am very proud of her work especially since she was drawing pokemon for the first time. I hope she would like to enter again next year.
For her reward i will be taking her to her favorite restaurant, Cosmo. She enjoys the sushi there.
We went the week after the the results were announced and she had a great time :)
Have thoughts or questions? Curious about this topic? Let‚Äôs chat about it.
Leave a comment on ùïè ‚Äî I‚Äôd love to hear from you!
My 8 year old daughters entry for the e4 art contesthttps://t.co/8TynsPApCF
— PokiPlanet (@pokiplanet) June 30, 2025
title: E4 Art & Illustration Contest 2025

content:
Pikachu (4) - First Move Black Star Promo - Signed by Veronica Taylor, Voice of Ash KetchumAbout #Veronica TaylorVeronica Taylor is best known for her dubbing work in English-language adaptations of Japanese anime, in particular for voicing Ash Ketchum and his mother Delia in the Pok√©mon anime for its first eight seasons.
The Pikachu (4) Promo card was give as one of four possible Wizards Black Star Promos that people could receive with the purchase of a ticket for the theatrical release of Pok√©mon: The First Movie (Mewtwo Strikes Back) starting November 12, 1999.
Pikachu Promo CardThis particular signed Pikachu connects to Veronica Taylor through her role as Ash Ketchum in Pok√©mon: The First Movie, her attendance at the LA premiere, and the card‚Äôs status as a promotional item tied to the film. The signature personalizes this collectible, linking her voice acting legacy to a key moment in Pok√©mon‚Äôs history.
Looking for more? #You can view my personal collection here Have thoughts or questions? Curious about this topic? Let‚Äôs chat about it.
Leave a comment on ùïè ‚Äî I‚Äôd love to hear from you!
https://t.co/oRkYRWBOog
— PokiPlanet (@pokiplanet) July 23, 2025
title: PSA AUTO 10 Veronica Taylor Signed Pikachu

content:
Lopunny (116/DP-P) - 2008 Collection Challenge : DP Exchange Japanese PromoAbout #The Collection Challenge: DP Exchange Card event was a promotional campaign held in Japan from Saturday 2 August ÔΩû Sunday 31 August 2008 at card game stores nationwide. Pok√©mon fans were encouraged to bring 2 holofoil cards and trade them in return for a sealed pack containing the Buneary (115/DP-P) and Lopunny (116/DP-P) cards.
The event had guidelines such as:
“Replace with 2 Pok√©mon Kira cards.” (Kira = Shiny) “Trainer cards and energy cards cannot be exchanged.” “The quanity of each card is limited.” “The card will end as soon as it runs out.” “One gift per person (one each).” Sealed pack of Buneary (115/DP-P) and Lopunny(116/DP-P)This particular event was a part of a larger event “Collection Challenge” beginning July 4th 2008 in which;
“you can get original cards from various locations across the country. Participate in events and campaigns held at Pok√©mon movie theaters, Pok√©mon card game stores, etc. nationwide, collect various cards, and enjoy your collection to the fullest! The Pok√©mon differ depending on where you get the card, and the illustrations and moves are original to the Pok√©mon card game “Collection Challenge”, so it’s truly a valuable card that can only be obtained here!!”
Below are a few links from the Pok√©mon company about the event that have been archived.
Collection Challenge Collection Challenge Card List Looking for more? #You can view my personal collection here Have thoughts or questions? Curious about this topic? Let‚Äôs chat about it.

https://t.co/gIuXjlzaIG
— PokiPlanet (@pokiplanet) July 7, 2025
title: PSA 10 Lopunny Collection Challenge Event

content:
1999 Base Set - Unlimited - Venusaur 15/102 - HoloAbout #Venusaur 15/102 from the Pok√©mon Base Set holds a significant place in the history of the Pok√©mon Trading Card Game. Released in North America on January 9, 1999, by Wizards of the Coast, the Base Set was the first English-language set of Pok√©mon cards, adapted from the Japanese Pok√©mon Card Game launched by Media Factory in 1996. The Base Set introduced players to the original 151 Pok√©mon from the Pok√©mon Red and Blue video games, with Venusaur 15/102 being one of the set‚Äôs flagship holographic (holo) cards. Venusaur, alongside Charizard and Blastoise, forms the “Big 3” of the Base Set‚Äîthree iconic Stage 2 Pok√©mon that became the most coveted cards due to their rarity, power, and cultural significance. These cards represent the final evolutions of the starter Pok√©mon from the Pok√©mon Red and Blue games (Bulbasaur, Charmander, and Squirtle), resonating deeply with fans of the franchise. The Unlimited print, while not as scarce as First Edition, was still highly sought after due to its holographic shine and the nostalgia tied to the early Pok√©mon craze of the late 1990s.
Looking for more? #You can view my personal collection here Have thoughts or questions? Curious about this topic? Let‚Äôs chat about it.
Leave a comment on ùïè ‚Äî I‚Äôd love to hear from you!
https://t.co/YmCWCcDo89
— PokiPlanet (@pokiplanet) July 2, 2025
title: PSA 9 Venusaur Base Set Holo

content:
Dragonite FB (018/DPt-P) Beat of the Frontier Release Commemoration Tournament PrizeAbout #The 2009 Beat of the Frontier Release Commemoration Tournament, part of the Pok√©mon Trading Card Game (TCG) Challenge Hiroba events in Japan, was held to celebrate the release of the Beat of the Frontier expansion (released in English as Supreme Victors) on March 6, 2009. These events were designed to promote the Pok√©mon TCG by hosting tournaments in large public venues like shopping malls and department stores, increasing accessibility and awareness compared to the more traditional Pok√©mon Card Gym events held in hobby shops.
Participation and performance in the tournaments were rewarded with exclusive promotional cards
‚Ä¢	Participation Prize: All participants received a SP Energy card (cosmos holofoil). Some locations also distributed a Pikachu cosmos holofoil card, which had previously been awarded at the Battle Road 2008 events. This was likely due to leftover stock from the prematurely canceled Battle Road 2008.
‚Ä¢	One Win: Players who won at least one match received a Battle Tower card (cosmos holofoil, DPt-P Promotional print) stamped with the Beat of the Frontier expansion logo on the bottom right of the illustration. This card was part of the Supreme Victors expansion in English.
‚Ä¢	Two Wins: Players achieving two wins were awarded a Dragonite FB (Frontier Brain‚Äôs) card (cosmos holofoil, DPt-P Promotional print), also stamped with the Beat of the Frontier expansion logo. This card was a notable prize for its rarity and connection to the Frontier Brains theme.
‚Ä¢	Winner: Winners of the tournament would receive a Drifblim card, also stamped with the set‚Äôs logo.
Looking for more? #You can view my personal collection here Have thoughts or questions? Curious about this topic? Let‚Äôs chat about it.
Leave a comment on ùïè ‚Äî I‚Äôd love to hear from you!
https://t.co/XjSz8LiBF8
— PokiPlanet (@pokiplanet) June 25, 2025
title: PSA 10 Dragonite FB Tournament Prize

content:
Cresselia (020/L-P) Super Rank PrizeAbout #The Cresselia 020/L-P Japanese Promo is a rare and highly sought-after Pok√©mon card released exclusively through the Pok√©mon Daisuki Club in Japan.
Established in January 2004, the Pok√©mon Daisuki Club was a Japanese fan club for Pok√©mon enthusiasts, covering the video games, anime, and Trading Card Game (TCG). It required an annual membership fee and a Japanese address for registration. Members received a membership card and could earn Action Points (AP) by participating in events, tournaments, contests, surveys, and other activities. Members accumulated “AP” to achieve ranks, with higher ranks unlocking exclusive promotional cards.
The card was Awarded to members who reached “Super Rank” by accumulating 3,200 AP. This was the highest rank in 2008 and remained a significant milestone in 2009 and beyond. The card was part of a set with Darkrai 021/L-P, given together to Super Rank members starting in 2009. The sealed packet also included cosmos holofoil Psychic and Dark Basic Energy cards from the 2009 Gym Challenge events.
Looking for more? #You can view my personal collection here Have thoughts or questions? Curious about this topic? Let‚Äôs chat about it.
Leave a comment on ùïè ‚Äî I‚Äôd love to hear from you!
https://t.co/5JY7BDoDgO
— PokiPlanet (@pokiplanet) June 23, 2025
title: PSA 10 Cresselia Daisuki Club Super Rank Prize

Manaphy (004/PPP) Fan Club 3,000 EXP PointsAbout #The 2007 Manaphy 004/PPP Japanese Promo Pok√©mon card is a rare, holofoil promotional card released exclusively through the Pok√©mon Players Club in Japan, officially known as the Pok√©mon Card Game‚Äôs Players Club (PCGP).
The card was awarded to members of the Pok√©mon Players Club in the year 2007 who accumulated 3,000 Experience Points. The Pok√©mon Players Club, established in January 2003 as the successor to the original Pok√©mon Fan Club, was a program designed to engage dedicated Pok√©mon fans in Japan. Members could earn EXP through various activities, such as:
Participating in tournaments
Entering contests
Completing surveys or quizzes
Engaging in other club-related activities
Looking for more? #You can view my personal collection here Have thoughts or questions? Curious about this topic? Let‚Äôs chat about it.

content:
While going through my old console collection one day, I came across a metal carry case featuring Rayquaza that‚Äôs just the right size to fit a Game Boy Advance SP inside.
After searching online, I couldn‚Äôt find much about it, just a few eBay listings but no one seemed to really know anything about it. I submitted a post on elitefourum.com and continued my research, but ultimately hit a dead end.
Now a Collectible #More recently, in 2025, this item has become something of a collectible. More and more collectors are searching for information about it, and while more are appearing on the secondhand market, the travel case remained a mystery. Knowledge of its existence has primarily circulated through online forums, Reddit threads, and collector groups often accompanied by vague recollections.
Personal Research #As someone who personally owned this case, I recall purchasing it as part of a Pok√©mon Emerald bundle from a Toys ‚ÄúR‚Äù Us store in the UK. However, unlike what I had heard from others, I don‚Äôt remember purchasing a Game Boy Advance SP with it, I already owned one and just purchased the game.
Using Archive.org‚Äôs Wayback Machine, I searched archived versions of the UK Toys ‚ÄúR‚Äù Us website from around the game‚Äôs release. After combing through dozens of captures, I still couldn‚Äôt find any promotional material on their homepage, so I switched to a more in-depth search of their product pages. Finally, I found it.
Screenshot from archive.org - Jan-03-2006Though the image quality was poor, this confirmed what my memory had preserved: this case was a Toys ‚ÄúR‚Äù Us exclusive.
The listing reads:
GBA Pok√©mon Emerald
Long-awaited Pok√©mon Emerald plus exclusive Travel Case.
Unfortunately, the actual listing itself has not been archived, and I still haven‚Äôt managed to find any additional information. However, I do remember there being promotional material in-store at Toys ‚ÄúR‚Äù Us at the time, so hopefully more will surface in the future.
Details of the Case #Here‚Äôs what is known about the case:
Material: Metal shell Design: Custom-molded to snugly fit a GBA SP. Strap: Green nylon/fabric strap Availability: Bundled with Pok√©mon Emerald at Toys ‚ÄúR‚Äù Us UK stores (and possibly through their website). Era: Released alongside the European release of Pok√©mon Emerald around October 21, 2005. Sold out by 2006 Inside: Contains two grey foam inserts (top and bottom) for padding; lined with smooth black fabric Conclusion #The Rayquaza Game Boy Advance SP travel case serves as a reminder of a time when gaming accessories were more regionally unique and often fleeting in availability. While it may not have the recognition of limited-edition consoles or tournament prizes, its rarity and connection to one of the most beloved Pok√©mon titles give it a unique place in collecting history.
Thanks to tools like Archive.org and the dedication of nostalgic fans, small fragments of gaming history like this continue to be uncovered and appreciated. If you happen to own one, consider yourself lucky, you hold a piece of forgotten Pok√©mon memorabilia that many are still searching for more information about.
Have thoughts or questions? Curious about this topic? Let‚Äôs chat about it.
Leave a comment on ùïè ‚Äî I‚Äôd love to hear from you!
The origin of the Pok√©mon Emerald Rayquaza Metal GBA SP Travel Casehttps://t.co/3B33y416ld
— PokiPlanet (@pokiplanet) June 7, 2025
title: Pok√©mon Emerald Rayquaza Metal GBA SP Case

content:
The Diamond & Pearl Trainer Kit (featuring Manaphy and Lucario) was released in the Diamond & Pearl era, but some versions of these kits were known to include booster packs from late EX-series sets. These late EX-series packs were produced before the full transition into the Diamond & Pearl sets and can be a significant treat for collectors, as they tend to be harder to find today.
Likely Booster Packs Included: #The contents of the Diamond & Pearl Trainer Kit varied over time and across different print runs, but here are the key booster packs you might find:
Diamond & Pearl Base Set Most common pack to be included, as this is the core set of the Diamond & Pearl era.
Mysterious Treasures Second most common pack to appear, also from the Diamond & Pearl block, and highly sought after by players due to the unique cards it includes (like Electivire and Mew).
Secret Wonders A slightly rarer pack that introduces several beloved cards and mechanics from the Diamond & Pearl era.
Great Encounters Another set from the Diamond & Pearl era, notable for powerful cards like Garchomp and Lugia.
Majestic Dawn Less common in packs but still a possibility, known for powerful Legendary Pok√©mon and cards like Dialga and Palkia.
Late EX Series Packs: #Beyond the Diamond & Pearl sets, some Trainer Kits were reported to contain booster packs from the later EX-series, particularly from 2005‚Äì2007. These were part of the tail end of the EX era, and getting one of these packs adds significant rarity and potential value to the Trainer Kit. The most notable packs include:
EX Holon Phantoms Rarity: Relatively rare but occasionally included in later print runs of the Trainer Kits.
EX Power Keepers Rarity: Sometimes included in Trainer Kits, though less frequently than Holon Phantoms.
EX Legend Maker Rarity: Less common, but still possible to find in Trainer Kits.
EX Deoxys Rarity: Very rare in the Trainer Kit, but certainly possible.
Likely Pack Combinations: #The most common packs will still be from the Diamond & Pearl era, as those were the sets in active circulation when the Trainer Kits were released.
EX-series packs are considered rarer, but can sometimes be found so it‚Äôs more of a special bonus for those lucky enough to find one.
The following breakdown is not official, just what we can assume from current data available.
Rarity Breakdown: Diamond & Pearl Base Set ‚Äì ~50% chance (most common)
Mysterious Treasures ‚Äì ~20-25% chance
Secret Wonders ‚Äì ~15-20% chance
Great Encounters ‚Äì ~10-15% chance
Majestic Dawn ‚Äì ~5-10% chance
EX Holon Phantoms ‚Äì ~5% chance (rarer)
EX Power Keepers ‚Äì ~5% chance (rarer)
EX Legend Maker / EX Deoxys ‚Äì <5% chance (very rare)
Conclusion: #The Diamond & Pearl Trainer Kit is primarily designed around the Diamond & Pearl series, but it‚Äôs certainly possible to find late EX-series packs mixed in, particularly in certain batches of the product. These packs are more rare, but they add an exciting element for collectors hunting for EX-era cards.
If you’re hoping for a specific set like EX, your odds are fairly low, but the possibility certainly exists!
Let’s test! #I decided to purchase a Diamond & Pearl Trainer Kit from eBay. Snagged one from an auction for only
When the package arrived, I carefully inspected the sealed product, scanning for any signs of wear or tampering. I wanted to ensure I wasn‚Äôt about to open something that had been messed with.
Whilst inspecting, I noticed that the edge of the booster pack was visible through the side of the plastic. The light hit it just right, and I could make out enough of the artwork to start formulating a guess about which set it could be from.
After a closer look at the booster pack‚Äôs art, I began comparing it with the different pack arts from all the sets we previously covered what it could be. There are a lot of possibilities, and I ended up thinking the pack featured Kabutops, The colors and design seemed to line up, and I grew confident that I had an EX Holon Phantoms pack in my hands.
I decided to open the kit and record it for fun, sort of like a booster pack opening! You can watch the full opening on my YouTube:
Unwrapping the kit, I was greeted with a surprise: it wasn‚Äôt Kabutops after all. Instead, the pack featured Zangoose!
Though I had been wrong about the pack art, I wasn‚Äôt disappointed in the slightest! It was still an EX Holon Phantoms pack like i had hoped for, and it felt like a stroke of luck that I‚Äôd pulled a pack from this sought-after set. In the end, my guess had been close enough, and it was a fun experience learning about this product.
Have thoughts or questions? Curious about this topic? Let‚Äôs chat about it.
Leave a comment on ùïè ‚Äî I‚Äôd love to hear from you!
The Diamond & Pearl Trainer Kit has a rare chance at containing a late EX-era Booster Pack inside. Read more üëáhttps://t.co/Mo7qbGjqY0
— PokiPlanet (@pokiplanet) May 2, 2025
title: Inside The Diamond & Pearl Trainer Kit

content:
What is the Black Flame Ninetales?
If you asked that question to an AI today, you might get a response like the one ChatGPT gave me here:
The oldest cited source, and the first image used in many of those responses, comes from a post I made on EliteFourum (formerly elitefourum.proboards.com) all the way back in October 2020.
I was intrigued after spotting a version of Base Set Ninetales in the wild that looked noticeably different. At the time, there was barely any information about it online, so I dug deeper and decided to create a post documenting the card on EliteFourum. That post gained significant attention within the collecting community. Some collectors had already noticed the variant and had been quietly acquiring them for years.
The new information I shared prompted more collectors to come forward with additional research and insights into this mysterious card. Eventually, this community effort led to collectors formally requesting that the grading company CGC recognize the variant using my article as a key reference point.
Thanks to the support of the collectors at EliteFourum and the research I contributed, CGC officially recognized the card as a variant on February 9th, 2021. They even published their own article on the subject, which you can read here:
üëâ CGC article on the Black Flame Ninetales
Since then the card has become more recognized in the community as well as other leading grading companies have officially recognized the variant too like PSA.
I‚Äôm incredibly proud to have made a lasting impact on the Pok√©mon TCG community and grateful to the fellow collectors at EliteFourum who helped along the way.
Below is a copy of the original article I wrote five years ago. For more discussion and collector insights, I highly recommend checking out the original thread here:
üîó The Black Flame Ninetales ‚Äì EliteFourum
Original Article (October 2020) #The Black Flame Ninetales #For those that are seeing this for the first time it‚Äôs an Unlimited Base Set Ninetales (12/102) but the flame around Ninetales is black instead of purple.
(See side by side comparison below)
After searching ebay for a few month‚Äôs checking every Ninetales card listed i managed to find one on a BIN and scooped it up, Having it in hand i was now determined to find out some more information about it starting with evidence of it being pulled from a pack.
It took a while searching through pack opening videos for every time a Ninetales was pulled but i finally found one being pulled from 6 years a go!
PrimetimePokemon‚Äôs Pull (Timestamp: 10:52)See also LeonHart‚Äôs pack opening video found by @jkanly
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=q0MU7sAmMVY
You can see in these video‚Äôs that the Booster Packs being opened are;
Identifying Shadowless & Unlimited Base set Boxes & Packs
Made in the U.S.A., ‚Äú1999-2000‚Äù copywrites, Short seal pack: There is no evidence this card comes from any other pack as of yet.
Error or Variant? #My initial theory was that it‚Äôs an error card since the packs it comes from are a late print of Unlimited but the Black Flame is not present on previous print runs of Unlimited, leading me to speculate that it was a possible printing error.
However keep in mind that a 1999-2000 Base Set Booster Pack is not guaranteed to have a 1999-2000 print Holo card inside, it has been rumoured that the non-2000 print holo‚Äôs inside the packs are old stock, Possibly from an early print run of Unlimited. This would make the most sense as the Black Flame Ninetales shares it‚Äôs black flame with the Shadowless & 1st Edition versions and it is also not a 1999-2000 print holo.
Additional Information #The black flame is also clearly visible on all 1st Edition, Shadowless, Japanese Base Set & Evolutions Ninetales as well. These are the only other prints that contain the black flame that i have found. All other Languages of Unlimited Base Set as well as the 1999-2000 Print, Base Set 2 & Legendary Collection Ninetales have the purple flame.
I would still love to find out more about this card. If you know any more information about it or have some theories please share! There is still a ton i don‚Äôt know but i am grateful for the efour community teaching me new things daily so please let me know if anything is wrong & i will correct it. Finally i encourage you to check through your binders to see if you have one of these super rare Ninetales and share it below üòÑ
Thanks to: #@alovell ‚Äì for sharing his thread were he found one of these error‚Äôs. @jkanly ‚Äì for his brilliant guide helping me determine which packs the error comes from. PrimetimePokemon ‚Äì for opening a Base Booster Box 6 years ago. @fritz ‚Äì for getting the first ever Black Flame Ninetales graded with CGC as well as his YouTube video about this card. œûœû(‡πë‚öà ‚Ä§Ã´ ‚öà‡πë)‚à©
Changelog #9th October 2020 ‚Äì Added LeonHart‚Äôs pack opening (credit @jkanly) 9th February 2021 ‚Äì Black Flame Ninetales officially recognized by CGC ‚û§ CGC article link 4th March 2021 ‚Äì Error or Variant? : removed mention of it being an error card & added additional information regarding possible history of the card. Have thoughts or questions? Curious about this topic? Let‚Äôs chat about it.
Leave a comment on ùïè ‚Äî I‚Äôd love to hear from you!
5 years ago, I discovered the mysterious Black Flame Ninetales‚Äîa Base Set variant with a unique holo pattern.
That research helped CGC officially recognize the card.
Here‚Äôs the full story behind one of Pok√©mon TCG‚Äôs rarest oddities üëáhttps://t.co/Q8iytUjV2Z

title: The Black Flame Ninetales
